title: CAUSATIVE VERBS: HAVE • GET • MAKE • LET
subtitle: Structure • Example • Short Explanation

sections.heading: PAYING FOR A SERVICE
examples: I have my shirts ironed every week.
I get my shirts ironed every week.
I had my window repaired.
I got my window repaired.
I'm having my pool cleaned tomorrow.
I might have my boat repainted.
sections.explanation: You don't do the action. You pay someone to do it. 'Have' = slightly formal. 'Get' = more conversational.
sections.importantNote: Correct: I had my groceries delivered. Incorrect: I had delivered my groceries. (this becomes past perfect, not causative)

sections.heading: ASK / CONVINCE / PERSUADE (Have vs. Get)
examples: I'll have him take a look.
I can't get my son to sleep.
I have my students put their homework on my desk.
How do you get your students to listen to you?
I'll have my lawyer call you.
It's hard to get my parents to agree with me.
sections.explanation: Both can mean 'ask someone to do something,' but get usually means you must persuade / convince them. Have is more neutral.

sections.heading: FORCE (MAKE)
examples: The robbers made the guard give them the code.
My boss makes us work late on Fridays.
Stop making me laugh!
My kids make me cut the crusts off their sandwiches.
sections.explanation: Shows no choice. Stronger than 'get' or 'have.'

sections.heading: PERMISSION (LET)
structure: let = let, let, let (same in all forms)
examples: My professor let us use our phones during the test.
My sister lets me borrow her car.
My landlord won't let me have a pet.
Open the wine and let it breathe for 30 minutes.
sections.explanation: Shows permission or allowing something to happen.

summary.example: I can't get him to help.
They made him open the door.
She lets me borrow her bike.
